Class Result<T, TFailure>

The result type is used to eliminate the need for throwing exceptions. The idea is that a function that returns a result will either return a successful value or an error value. The methods of the Result type help you compose and deconstruct this information.

Inheritance
System.Object
Result<T, TFailure>
Result<T>
Namespace: FunctionalLink.Next
Assembly: FunctionalLink.Next.dll
Syntax
public class Result<T, TFailure> : Object

Name Description
T

The internal value type, if successful
TFailure

The internal failure type, if failed

Used to combine two Results if they are both successful

Parameters
Type Name Description
Result<TOther, TFailure> other

The second result to combine
System.Func<T, TOther, TResult> selector

The function used to combine the values from ResultA and B
Returns
Type Description
Result<TResult, TFailure>

If the Result was successful, the combined value of ResultA and B is returned. Otherwise, the failure from either ResultA or B will be returned

Operators

Implicit(Failure<TFailure> to Result<T, TFailure>)

An implicit conversion operator for reducing the amount of syntax required for creating failed Results.

Declaration
public static implicit operator Result<T, TFailure>(Failure<TFailure> failure)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Failure<TFailure> failure

The failure message
Returns
Type Description
Result<T, TFailure>

A Result of T
Remarks

Typically, this operator is used like so:

public static Result<int,string> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Success(a / b)
        : Failure("Cannot divide by zero"); // this Failure is implicitly converted to Result<int>

To avoid the implicit conversion, use the 'Failure' Result constructor directly:

public static Result<int,string> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Result<int,string>.Success(a / b)
        : Result<int,string>.Failure("Cannot divide by zero"); // no implicit conversion is done here

Implicit(Success<T> to Result<T, TFailure>)

An implicit conversion operator for reducing the amount of syntax required for creating successful Results.

Declaration
public static implicit operator Result<T, TFailure>(Success<T> success)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Success<T> success

The Success instance to convert
Returns
Type Description
Result<T, TFailure>

A Result of T
Remarks

Typically, this operator is used like so:

public static Result<int,string> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Success(a / b)  // this Success is implicitly converted to Result<int,string>
        : Failure("Cannot divide by zero");

To avoid the implicit conversion, use the 'Failure' Result constructor directly:

public static Result<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Result<int,string>;.Success(a / b)  // no implicit conversion is done here
        : Result<int,string>;.Failure("Cannot divide by zero");
